properties.description: The Tea Act was a specific British parliamentary act passed in 1773, which granted the British East India Company an exclusive and significant monopoly on all tea sales within the American colonies, profoundly impacting colonial trade.

The Boston Tea Party occurred in December 1773 when American colonists, notably led by Samuel Adams, defiantly boarded British ships and dumped British East India Company tea into Boston Harbor, signifying a major act of colonial rebellion.

This mechanism describes how the Tea Act led to colonial rebellion by fundamentally violating deeply held colonial principles of self-governance through the imposition of taxation without direct representation in Parliament, which further generated economic pressure on local merchants and political mobilization by groups like the Sons of Liberty.

The Tea Act directly caused the Boston Tea Party because it gave the British East India Company a significant monopoly on tea sales in the American colonies, which was perceived by colonists as an unjust economic and political imposition leading to rebellion.

Colonial rebellion, specifically exemplified by the Boston Tea Party, was primarily caused because the Tea Act violated fundamental colonial principles of self-governance by imposing taxation without representation in Parliament, which spurred widespread political and economic opposition.

Colonial pamphlets were widely distributed, specifically articulating detailed arguments and grievances against the British policy of taxation without direct representation, demonstrating a prevailing ideological opposition among colonists.

The Boston Tea Party garnered substantial and widespread support across numerous American colonies, indicating a broad consensus among the populace and demonstrating the effective operation of the underlying rebellious causal mechanism.
The historical text explicitly confirms the occurrence of the Boston Tea Party, detailing the key actors and specific actions taken, providing direct affirmation of the event's reality as described.
